hints_html:
The series

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} x^k\end{aligned}\]

converges for all values of x between -1 and 1.
hints_latex:
The series

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} x^k
\end{align*} converges for all values of \emph{x} between
-1 and 1.
hints_raw:
The series
:<math>
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} x^k
</math>
converges for all values of ''x'' between -1 and 1.
sols_html:
The first series

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x-\frac12\right)^k\end{aligned}\]

converges for all values of x such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -1 < x-\frac12 < 1\end{aligned}\]

which we can rewrite as

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -1+\frac12 < x < 1+\frac12\end{aligned}\]

that is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -\frac12 < x < \frac32\end{aligned}\]

The second series

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x+\frac12\right)^k\end{aligned}\]

converges for all values of x such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -1 < x+\frac12 < 1\end{aligned}\]

which we can rewrite as

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -1-\frac12 < x < 1-\frac12\end{aligned}\]

that is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -\frac32 < x < \frac12\end{aligned}\]

So values of x in the interval (-1/2,3/2) will make the first series converge and values in the interval (-3/2,1/2) will make the second series converge. Hence the values of x which make exactly one of the series convergent cannot be in the intersection of these two intervals. We can now conclude that that the set S is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle S = \left( -\frac32, -\frac12\right] \cup \left[ \frac12, \frac32 \right)\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The first series

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x-\frac12\right)^k
\end{align*} converges for all values
of \emph{x} such that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-1 < x-\frac12 < 1
\end{align*} which we can rewrite as

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-1+\frac12 < x < 1+\frac12
\end{align*} that is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-\frac12 < x < \frac32
\end{align*}

The second series

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x+\frac12\right)^k
\end{align*} converges for all values
of \emph{x} such that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-1 < x+\frac12 < 1
\end{align*} which we can rewrite as

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-1-\frac12 < x < 1-\frac12
\end{align*} that is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-\frac32 < x < \frac12
\end{align*}

So values of \emph{x} in the interval (-1/2,3/2) will make the first
series converge and values in the interval (-3/2,1/2) will make the
second series converge. Hence the values of \emph{x} which make
\emph{exactly} one of the series convergent cannot be in the
intersection of these two intervals. We can now conclude that that the
set \emph{S} is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
S = \left( -\frac32, -\frac12\right] \cup \left[ \frac12, \frac32 \right)
\end{align*}

:<math>\displaystyle
-1 < x-\frac12 < 1
</math>
which we can rewrite as
:<math>\displaystyle
-1+\frac12 < x < 1+\frac12
</math>
that is

</math>

The second series
:<math>
\sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x+\frac12\right)^k
</math>
converges for all values of ''x'' such that
:<math>\displaystyle
-1 < x+\frac12 < 1
</math>
which we can rewrite as
:<math>\displaystyle
-1-\frac12 < x < 1-\frac12
</math>
that is
:<math>\displaystyle
-\frac32 < x < \frac12
</math>

So values of ''x'' in the interval (-1/2,3/2) will make the first series converge and values in the interval (-3/2,1/2) will make the second series converge. Hence the values of ''x'' which make ''exactly'' one of the series convergent cannot be in the intersection of these two intervals. We can now conclude that that the set ''S'' is
:<math>\displaystyle
S = \left( -\frac32, -\frac12\right] \cup \left[ \frac12, \frac32 \right)
</math>
statement_html:
Define S to be the set of all real numbers x such that exactly one of the two series

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x-\frac{1}{2} \right)^k \quad\text{ and }\quad \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x+\frac{1}{2} \right)^k\end{aligned}\]

converges. Write down (with justification) a simple expression for S, using interval notation and set operations such as \(\cup\), \(\cap\) and / or -.
statement_latex:
Define \emph{S} to be the set of all real numbers \emph{x} such that
\emph{exactly one} of the two series

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x-\frac{1}{2} \right)^k \quad\text{ and }\quad \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x+\frac{1}{2} \right)^k
\end{align*}

converges. Write down (with justification) a simple expression for
\emph{S}, using interval notation and set operations such as $\cup$,
$\cap$ and / or -.
statement_raw:
Define ''S'' to be the set of all real numbers ''x'' such that ''exactly one'' of the two series

:<math>\sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x-\frac{1}{2} \right)^k \quad\text{ and }\quad \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x+\frac{1}{2} \right)^k </math>

converges. Write down (with justification) a simple expression for ''S'', using interval notation and set operations such as <math>\cup</math>, <math>\cap</math> and / or -.
